steps.title: Eat and drink well before and after each run.
steps.content: Eat and drink well before and after each run. [1] X Research source Have a power bar or banana at least half an hour before your run so that you will be adequately fueled throughout the run. [2] X Research source Afterwards, eat a good meal to help you recover from the workout. [3] X Research source Consider having a meal with high protein to help with recovery. Make sure you hydrate well before your run -- guzzling large amounts of water right before you start won't help hydrate you throughout a long run; in fact, doing that might give you painful running cramps. [4] X Expert Source Francisco Gomez Fitness Coach Expert Interview. 24 October 2019.

steps.title: Plan your run.
steps.content: Plan your run. Decide what distance you want to run and where you want to go. Consider factors like hills and running surfaces when planning your route. Hills tend to be harder to run. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Dress appropriately.
steps.content: Dress appropriately. Wear light weight running shoes that are in good condition and fit your feet well. Wear cool, comfortable clothes that will wick sweat while you run.

steps.title: Take a warm-up lap around the block, school, track, or any other place that will take a few minutes to run around.
steps.content: Take a warm-up lap around the block, school, track, or any other place that will take a few minutes to run around. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Do various stretches to help loosen your muscles.
steps.content: Do various stretches to help loosen your muscles. [7] X Expert Source Francisco Gomez Fitness Coach Expert Interview. 24 October 2019. Focus on the legs, but also stretch your arms, shoulders, back, and core.

steps.title: Complete your run.
steps.content: Complete your run. Try to run the whole way at a consistent pace. If you need to, walk for a few minutes before running again, but don't stop. Pay attention to your form: make sure not to be tense in the upper body, as this will tire you out much faster. Also, make sure to run from the middle of the foot to the toe (land on the ball of your foot and lift off from the toes).

steps.title: Breathe well.
steps.content: Breathe well. Breathing is important in running long distances and learning how to breathe while running can help tremendously. [8] X Research source

steps.title: After running, rest and drink water.
steps.content: After running, rest and drink water. Stretch well to minimize soreness after the run. [9] X Trustworthy Source National Health Service (UK) Public healthcare system of the UK Go to source

steps.title: Run every day.
steps.content: Run every day. This will help condition your body and get yourself used to running. This will be hard at first, but you will get stronger and start to feel more comfortable running.

steps.title: Gradually build up your distances each time you run.
steps.content: Gradually build up your distances each time you run. [10] X Expert Source Francisco Gomez Fitness Coach Expert Interview. 24 October 2019. If you have never run before start at 1 kilometer (0.62 mi). When you can comfortably run that, try to go a little farther. Gradually increase to 5 kilometers (3.1 mi), then 10 kilometers (6.2 mi). Continue to push yourself until you achieve your distance goal. [11] X Research source

steps.title: Enter some races!
steps.content: Enter some races! If you are in Junior High or High School join the track and cross country team, or join a local running club and enter races in your town or city. Try to get a personal best each time you do a race.

steps.title: Keep at it!
steps.content: Keep at it! Distance running is very difficult and not many people keep it up. But you can! People will really admire you for keeping at it, and you will be happier and healthier throughout your life.
